editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Eastward ho as it was played in the Blackfriars. By the children of her majesty's revels
Made by Geo: Chapman. Ben: Jonson. Jon: Marston.
At London printed for William Aspley. 1605.

lg.l: Not out of envy, for there's no effect
Where there's no cause; nor out of imitation
For we have evermore been imitated;
Nor out of our contention to do better
Than that which is opposed to ours in title,
For that was good; and better cannot be:
And for the title if it seem affected
We might as well have called it, God you good even:
Only that eastward; westwards still exceeds,
Honour the sun's fair rising, not his setting;
Nor is our title utterly enforced,
As by the points we touch at, you shall see;
Bear with our willing pains, if dull or witty,
We only dedicate it to the city.

div.head: Actus primi, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter master Touchstone, and quicksilver at several doors, quicksilver with his hat, pumps, short sword and dagger, and a racket trussed up under his cloak. At the middle door, enter Golding discovering a goldsmith's shop, and walking short turns before it.

sp.speaker: Touchstone.
sp.p: And whether with you now? what loose action are you bound for? come what comrades are you to meet withal? where's the supper? where's the supper? where's the rendezvous?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Indeed, and in very good sober truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Indeed, and in very good sober truth sir? Behind my back thou wilt swear faster than a French foot boy, and talk more bawdily than a common midwife, and now indeed and in very good sober truth sir: but if a privy search should be made, with what furniture are you rigged now? Sirrah I tell thee, I am thy master William Tutchstone goldsmith: and thou my prentice Francis quicksilver: and will see whether you are running. Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why sir I hope a man may use his recreation with his master's profit.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Prentices recreations are seldom with their master's profit. Work upon that now. You shall give up your cloak though you be no alderman. Heyday, ruffian's hall. Sword, pumps, here's a racket indeed. Touch. uncloakes Quick.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou shameless varlet dost thou jest at thy lawful master contrary to thy indentures?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Why 'zblood sir, my mother's a gentlewoman: and my father a justice of peace, and of quorum, and though I am a younger brother and a prentice yet I hope I am my father's son: and by God's lid, 'tis for your worship and for your commodity that I keep company. I am entertained among gallants,
true: they call me cozen Frank, right; I lend them moneys, good; they spend it, well. But when they are spent, must not they strive to get more? must not their land fly? and to whom? shall not your worship ha, the refusal? well, I am a good member of the city if I were well considered. How would merchants thrive, if gentlemen would not be unthrifts? How could gentlemen be unthrifts if their humours were not fed? How should their humours be fed but by whit meat, and cunning secondings? well, the city might consider us. I am going to an ordinary now; the gallants fall to play, I carry light gold with me: the gallants call cozen Frank some gold for silver, I change, gain by it, the gallants lose the gold; and then call cozen Francke lend me some silver. Why —

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: Why? I cannot tell, seven score pound art thou out in the cash, but look to it, I will not be gallanted out of my moneys. And as for my rising by other men's fall; God shield me. Did I gain my wealth by ordinaries? no: by exchanging of gold? no: by keeping of gallants company? no. I hired me a little shop, fought low, took small gain, kept no debt book, garnished my shop for want of plate, with good wholesome thrifty sentences; as, Touchstone, keep thy shop, and thy shop will keep thee. Light gains makes heavy purses. 'tis good to be merry and wise: and when I was wived, having something to stick too, I had the horn of suretyship ever before my eyes: you all know the device of the horn, where the young fellow slips in at the butt end, and comes squeezed out at the Buckall: and I grew up, and I praise providence, I bear my brows now as high as the best of my neighbours: but thou-well look to the accounts, your father's bond lies for you: seven score pound is yet in the rear.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why 'slid sir, I have as good, as proper gallants words for it as any are in London, gentlemen of good phrase, perfect language, passingly behaved, gallants that wear socks and clean linen, and call me kind cozen Frank, good cousin Frank, for they know my father; and by god; lid shall not I trust hem? not trust?

div.stage: Enter a page as enquiring for touchstones shop.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: What do ye lack sir? What is't you'll buy sir?

sp.speaker: Touchstone.
sp.p: I marry sir, there's a youth of another piece. There's thy fellow-prentice, as good a gentleman born as thou art: nay, and better meaned. But dos he pump it, or racket it? Well, if he thrive not, if he outlast not a hundred such crackling bavins as thou art, God and men neglect industry.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It is his shop, and here my m. walks. To the page.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: With me boy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My master, sir petronel flash, recommends his love to you, and will instantly visit you,

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: To make up the match with my eldest daughter, my wife's dilling, whom she longs to call madam. He shall find me unwillingly ready boy. Exit page.

There's another affliction too. As I have two prentices: the one of a boundless prodigality, the other of a most hopeful industry. So have I only two daughters: the eldest, of a proud ambition and nice wantonness: the other of a modest humility and comely soberness. The one must be ladyfied forsooth: and be attired just to the court-cut, and long tail. So far is she ill natured to the place and means of my preferment and fortune, that she throws all the contempt and despite, hatred itself can cast upon it. Well, a piece of land she has, was her grandmothers gift: let her, and her sir petronel, flash out that. But as for my substance, she that scorns me, as I am a citizen and tradesman, shall never pamper her pride with my industry: shall never use me as men do foxes; keep themselves warm in the skin, and throw the body that bore it to the dunghill. I must go entertain this sir petronel. Goulding, my utmost care's for thee, and only trust in thee, look to the shop, as for you, master quicksilver, think of husks, for thy course is running directly to the prodigaills hog's trough. husks Sra. works upon that now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Marry seek goodman flatcap: 'sfoot though I am a prentice I can give arms, and my father's a justice a peace by descent: and 'zblood —

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Fie how you swear.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
'Sfoot man I am a gentleman, and may swear by my pedigree, god's my life. Sirrah Goulding, wilt be ruled by a fool? turn good fellow, turn swaggering gallant, and let the welkin roar, and Erebus also: look not westward to the fall of don Phoebus, but to the East; eastward ho,
"Where radiant beams of lusty solemnising appear,
" and bright eovs makes the welkin clear. we are both gentlemen, and therefore should be no coxcombs: let's be no longer fools to this flatcap Touchstone. Eastward bully: this satin belly, and canvas backed touchstone; 'slife man his father was a maltman, and his mother sold gingerbread in christchurch.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: What would ye ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why do nothing, be like a gentleman, be idle the curse of man is labour. Wipe thy bum with testones, and make ducks and drakes with shillings: what eastward ho. Wilt thou cry, what is't ye lack? stand with a bare pate, and a dropping nose, under a wooden penthouse, and art a gentleman? wilt thou bear tankards, and mayst bear aims? be ruled, turn gallant, eastward ho, ta lyre, lyre, ro., Who calls Jeronimo? speak here I am: gods so, how like a sheep thou lookest, a my conscience some cowherd begotten thee, thou Goulding of Goulding-hall, ha boy?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: Go, ye are a prodigal coxcomb, I a cowherd's son, because I turn not a drunken whorehunting rakehell like thyself? Offers to draw, and Goulding trips up his heels and holds him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Rakehell? rakehell?

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Pish, in soft terms ye are a cowardly bragging boy. I'll ha' you whipped.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Whipped, that's good i'faith, untruss me?

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p:
No, thou wilt undo thyself. Alas I behold thee with pity, not with anger; thou common shot-clog, gull of all companies: methinks I see thee already walking in Moor fields without a cloak, with half a hat, without a band, a doublet with three buttons, without a girdle,
a hose with one point and no garter, with a cudgel under thine arm borrowing and begging three pence.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Nay 'slife, take this and take all: as I am a gentleman born, I'll be drunk, grow valiant, and beat thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Go thou most madly vain, whom nothing can recover but that which reclaims atheists, and makes great persons sometimes religious: calamity. As for my place and life thus I have read:

lg.l: Whate'er some vainer youth may term disgrace,
The gain of honest pains is never base:
From trades from arts, from valour honour springs,
These three are founts of gentry, yea of Kings.

div.stage: Enter Girtred, Mildrid, Bettrice, and Poldauy a tailor, Poldauy with a fair gown, Scotch varthing all, and French fall in his arms, girted in a French head attire, and citizen's gown; Mildred sowing, and Bettrice leading a monkey after her.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: For the passion of patience, look if sir petronel approach; that sweet, that fine, that delicate, that — for love's sake tell me if he come. O sister mill, though my father be a low capped tradesman, yet I must be a lady: and I praise God my mother must call me Medam, (Does he come?) off with this gown for shames sakes, off with this gown: let not my knight take me in the city cut in any hand: tear't, pax on't (Does he come) tear't of. Thus whilst she sleeps I sorrow, for her sake, etc.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Lord sister, with what an immodest impatiency and disgraceful scorn, do you put off your city tier: I am sorry to think you imagine to right yourself, in wronging that which hath made both you and us.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p:
I tell you I cannot endure it, I must be a lady: do you wear your quoiffe with a London licket; your stammel petticoat with two guards, the buffin gown with the tuftaffitic cape, and the velvet lace. I must be a lady, and I will be a lady. I like some humours of the city dames well, to eat cherries only at an angel a pound, good; to die rich scarlet black, pretty: to line a Grogaram gown clean
through with velvet, tolerable; their pure linen, their smocks of 3. li. A smock are to be born withal. But your mincing niceries, taffeta pipkins, durance petticoats, and silver bodkins: — gods my life, as I shall be a lady I cannot endure it. Is he come yet? Lord what a long knight 'tis! And ever she cried shout home, and yet I knew one longer, and ever she cried shout home, fa, la, lie, re, lo, la.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Well sister, those that scorn their nest, oft fly with a sick wing.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Boe-bell.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Where titles presume to thrust before fit means to second them, wealth and respect often grow sullen and will not follow. For sure in this, I would for your sake I spoke not truth. Where ambition of place goes before fitness of birth, contempt and disgrace follow. I heard a scholar once say, that Ulysses when he counterfeited himself mad, yoked cats, and foxes, and dogs together to draw his plough, whilst he followed and sowed salt: but sure I judge them truly mad, that yoke citizens and courtiers, trades men and soldiers, a goldsmith's daughter and a knight: well sister, pray God my father sow not salt too.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Alas, poor Mil. when I am a lady, I'll pray for thee yet i'faith: nay, and I'll vouchsafe to call thee sister Mil still, for though thou art not like to be a lady as I am, yet sure thou art a creature of gods making; and mayest peradventure to be saved as soon as I, (Dos he come?) And ever and anon she doubled in her song.

lg.l: Now (Ladies my comfort)
What a profane ape's here!
Tailor, Poldavis, prithee fit it
Fit it: is this a right scot?
Does it clip close? and bear up round?

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p:
Fine and stiffly i'faith, 'twill keep your thighs so cool and make your waste so small: here was a fault in your body, but I have supplied the defect, with the effect of my steel instrument
which, though it have but one eye, can see to rectify the imperfection of the proportion.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Most edifying tailor! I protest you tailors are most sanctified members, and make many crooked thing go upright. How must I bear my hands? light? light?

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p: O ay, now you are in the lady-fashion, you must do all things light. Tread light, light. I and fall so: that's the court-amble. She trips about the stage.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Has the court never a trot?

sp.speaker: Pold.
sp.p: No, but a false gallop, lady.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: And if she will not go to bedCantat.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: The knights come forsooth.

div.stage: Enter sir Petronell, m. Touchstone, and mistress Touchstone.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Is my knight come? O the lord. my band? Sister do my cheeks look well? give me a little box a the ear that I may see me to blush: now, now. So, there, there, there! here he is: oh my dearest delight, lord, lord, and how do my knight?

sp.speaker: Touch:
sp.p: Fie, with more modesty.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Modesty! why I am no citizen now, modesty? am I not to be married? you're best to keep me modest now I am to be a lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Petro.
sp.p: Boldness is good fashion and courtlike.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Ay, in a country lady I hope it is: as I shall be. And how chance ye came no sooner knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Petro.
sp.p: Faith, I was so entertained in the progress with one count Epernoum a Welsh knight: we had a match at balloon too, with my lord Whachum, for four crowns.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: At baboon? Jesu! you and I will play at baboon in the country? Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Pet.
sp.p: O sweet lady: 'tis a strong play with the arm.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: With arm, or leg, or any other member, if it be a court-sport. And when shall's be married my knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Pet.
sp.p: I come now to consummate it; and your father may call a poor knight, son in law.

sp.speaker: M. Touch.
sp.p:
Sir, ye are come, what is not mine to keep, I must not be sorry to forgo: a 100. li. Land her grandmother left her, 'tis yours, herself (As her mother's gift) is yours. But if
you expect ought from me, know, my hand and mine eyes open together; I do not give blindly: work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Sir Pet.
sp.p: Sir, you mistrust not my means? I am a knight.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sir, sir; what I know not, you will give me leave to say, I am ignorant of.

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: Yes, that he is a knight; I know where he had money to pay the gentlemen ushers, and heralds their fees. Ay, that he is a knight: and so might you have been too, if you had been ought else then an ass, as well as some of your neighbours. And I thought you would not ha' been knighted, (As I am an honest woman) I would ha' dubbed you myself, I praise God I have wherewithal. But as for you daughter. —

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: I mother, I must be a lady tomorrow: and by your leave mother (I speak it not without my duty, but only in the right of my husband) I must take place of you, mother.

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: That you shall lady-daughter, and have a coach as well as I too.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Yes mother. But by your leave mother, (I speak it not without my duty but only in my husband's right) my coach-horses must take the wall of your coach-horses.

sp.speaker: Touchstone.
sp.p: Come, come, the day grows low: 'tis supper time; use my house the wedding solemnity is at my wife's cost; thank me for nothing but my willing blessing: for (I cannot feign) my hopes are faint. And sir, respect my daughter, she has refused for you wealthy and honest matches, known good men, well moneyed, better traded, best reputed.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Body a truth, chittizens, chittizens. Sweet knight, as soon as ever we are married, take me to to thy mercy out of this miserable city, presently, carry me out of the scent of Newcastle coal, and the hearing of boe-bell, I beseech thee down with me for God sake.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Well daughter, I have read, that old wit sings:

lg.l: The greatest rivers flow from little springs.
Though thou art full, scorn not thy means at first,
He that's most drunk may soonest be a thirst.
Work upon that now.

sp.stage: All but Touchstone, Mildred, and Goulding depart.
sp.p: No, no; yond stand my hopes.

sp.speaker: Milared,
sp.p: Come hither daughter. And how approve you your sister's fashion? how do you fancy her cho ye? what dost thou think?

sp.speaker: Mil
sp.p: I hope as a sister, well.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay but, nay but how dost thou like her behaviour and humour? speak freely.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I am loath to speak ill: and yet I am sorry of this, I cannot speak well.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Well: very good, as I would wish: a modest answer ▪ Goulding, come hither: hither Golding. How dost thou like the knight. Sir flash? dos he not look big? how lik'st thou the elephant? he says he has a castle in the country.

sp.speaker: Gould.
sp.p: Pray heaven, the elephant carry not his castle on his back.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Fore heaven, very well: but seriously, how dost repute him?

sp.speaker: Gould.
sp.p: The best I can say of him is, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha Gulding ? I commend thee, I approve thee, and will make it appear my affection is strong to thee. My wife has her humour, and I will ha', mine. Dost thou see my daughter here? she is not fair, well-favoured or so, indifferent, which modest measure of beauty, shall not make it thy only work to watch her, nor sufficient mischance, to suspect her. Thou art towardly, she is modest, thou art provident, she is careful. She's now mine: give me thy hand, she's now thine ▪ work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Gould.
sp.p: Sir, as your son, I honour you; and as your servant obey you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sayest thou so, come hither Mildred. Do you see yond fellow? he is a gentlemen (Though my prentice) and has somewhat to take too: a youth of good hope; well friended, well parted. Are you mine ▪ you are his. Work (You) upon that now.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: Sir, I am all yours: your body gave me life, your care and love happiness of life: let your virtue still direct it, for to your wisdom I wholly dispose myself.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sayst thou so? be you two better acquainted. Lip her, lip her knave. So shut up shop: in ▪ we must make holiday.

lg.l: This match shall on, for I intend to proveEx. Gol. and Mil.
Which thrives the best, the mean or lofty love.
Whether fit wedlock vowed twixt like and like.
Or prouder hopes, which daringly o'er strike
Their place and means: 'tis honest time's expense.
When seeming lightness bears a moral sense.

sp.p: Work upon that now. Exit.

div.head: Actus secundi. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Touchstone, quicksilver, Goulding and Mildred, sitting on either side of the stall.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Quicksilver, master Frances quicksilver, master quicksilver? Enter quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Here sir;(Ump.)

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So sir; nothing but flat master quicksilver (Without any familiar addition) will fetch you: will you truss my points sir?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I forsooth:(Ump.)

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How now sir? the drunken hiccup, so soon this morning?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis but the coldness of my stomach forsooth.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What? have you the cause natural for it? you're a very learned drunkard: I believe I shall miss some of my silver spoons with your learning. The nuptial night will not moisten your throat sufficiently, but the morning likewise must rain her dews into your gluttonous weasand.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: An't please you sir, we did but drink(Ump,)to the coming off, of the knightly bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: To the coming off an'him?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I forsooth: we drunk to his coming on(Ump,)when we went to bed; and now we are up, we must drink to his coming off: for that's the chief honour of a soldier sir, and therefore we must drink so much the more to it, forsooth. (Ump.)

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A very capital reason. So that you go to bed late, and rise early to commit drunkenness? you fulfil the scripture very sufficient wickedly forsooth.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The knights men forsooth be still a their knees at it,(Ump)and because 'tis for your credit sir, I would be loath to flinch.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I pray sir, e'en to 'em again then; you're one of the seperated crew, one of my wife's faction, and my young ladies, with whom and with their great match, I will have nothing to do.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So sir, now I will go keep my(Ump)credit with 'em an't please you sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: In any case sir, lay one cup of sack more alyour cold stomach, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Yes forsooth. Exit. Quick.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This is for my credit servants ever maintain drunkenness in their master's house, for their master's credit; a good idle serving-man's reason: I thank time, the night is past; I ne'er waked to such cost; I think we have stowed more sorts of flesh in our bellies, then ever Noah's ark received: and for wine, why my house turns giddy with it, and more noise in it then at a conduct; ay me, even beasts condemn our gluttony. Well, 'tis our city's fault, which because we commit seldom, we commit the more sinfully, we lose no time in our sensuality, but we make amends for it; oh that we would do so in virtue, and religious negligences; but see here are all the sober parcels my house can show, I'll cavesdrop, hear what thoughts they utter this morning.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: But is it possible, that you seeing your sister preferred to the bed of a knight, should contain your affections in the arms of a prentice?

sp.speaker: Mill
sp.p: I had rather make up the garment of my affections in some of the same piece, then like a fool wear gowns of two colours, or mix sackcloth with satin.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: And do the costly garments; the title and fame of a lady the fashion; observation, and reverence proper to such preferment, no more inflame you, than such convenience as my poor means and industry can offer to your virtues?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.p: I have observed that the bridle given to those violent flatteries of fortune, is seldom recovered; they bear one headlong in desire from one novelty to another: and where those ranging appetites reign, there is ever more passion than reasons no stay, and so no happiness. These hasty advancements are not natural; nature hath given us legs, to go to our objects; not wings to fly to them.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: How dear an object you are to my desires I cannot express, whose fruition would my master's absolute consent and yours vouchsafe me, I should be absolutely happy. And though it were a grace so far beyond my merit, that I should blush with unworthiness to receive it, yet thus far both my love and my means shall assure your requital; you shall want nothing fit for your birth and education; what increase of wealth and advancement the honest and orderly industry and skill of our trade will afford in any, I doubt not will be aspired by me; I will ever make your contentment the end of my endeavours; I will love you above all; and only your grief shall be my misery; and your delight, my felicity.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Work upon that now. By my hopes, he woos honestly and orderly; he shall be anchor of my hopes. Look, see the ill yoked monster his fellow.

div.stage: Enter quicksilver unlaced, a towel about his neck, in his flat cap, drunk.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Eastward ho; holla ye pampered jades of Asia.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Drunk now down right, a, my fidelity.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: (Ump)pulldo, pulldo; show quoth the caliver.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Fie fellow quicksilver, what a pickle are you in?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Pickle? pickle in thy throat; zounes pickell? wa ha ho, good morrow knight petronel: morrow lady goldsmith ▪ come of, knight, with a counterbuff, for the honour of knighthood.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Why how now sir? do ye know where you are?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Where I am? why 'sblood you loulthead where I am?

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Go to, go to, for shame go to bed, and sleep out this immodesty: thou shamest both my master and his house.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Shame? what shame? I thought, thou wouldst show thy bringing up: and thou wert a gentleman as I am, thou wouldst think it no shame to be drunk. Lend me some money, save my credit, I must dine with the serving men and their wives; and their wife's sirrah.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: E'en who you will, I'll not lend thee three pence.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Sfoot lend me some money, hast thou not hyren here?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Why how now sirrah? what vain's this, hah?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Who cries on murder? lady was it you? how does our master? pray thee cry eastward ho?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, you're passed your hickup now, I see you're drunk.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: 'Tis for your credit master.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And hear you keep a whore in town.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: 'Tis for your credit master.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And what you are out in cash, I know.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So do I. My fathers a gentleman, work upon that now; eastward ho.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sir, eastward ho, will make you go westward ho; I will no longer dishonest my house, nor endanger my stock with your licence; there sir, there's your indenture, all your apparel (That I must know) is on your back; and from this time my door is shut to you: from me be free; but for other freedom, and the moneys you have wasted; eastward ho, shall not serve you.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Am I free a, my fetters? Rinse; fly with a duck in thy mouth: and now I tell thee touchstone —

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: When this eternal substance of my soul,

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Well said, change your gold ends for your play ends.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Did live imprisoned in my wanton flesh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What then sir?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: I was a courtier in the Spanish court, and don Andrea was my name.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Good master don Andrea will you march?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Sweet Touchstone, will you lend me two shillings?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Not a penny? I have friends, and I have acquaintance, I will piss at thy shop posts, and throw rotten eggs at thy sign: work upon that now. Exit, staggering.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Now sirrah, you? hear you? you shall serve me no more neither; not an hour longer.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: What mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I mean to give thee thy freedom; and with thy freedom my daughter: and with my daughter a father's love. And with all these such a portion, as shall make knight petronel himself envy thee: you're both agreed? are ye not?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: With all submission, both of thanks and duty.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: Well then, the great power of heaven bless and confirm you. And, Goulding, that my love to thee may not show less than my wife's love to my eldest daughter; thy marriage feast shall equal the knights and hers.

sp.speaker: Goul.
sp.p: Let me beseech you, no sir, the superfluity and cold meat left at their nuptials, will with bounty furnish ours. The grossest prodigality is superfluous cost of the belly: nor would I wish any invitement of states or friends, only your reverent presence and witness shall sufficiently grace and confirm us.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Son to mine own bosom, take her and my blessing: the nice fondling, my lady sir-reverence, that I must not now presume to call daughter, is so ravished with desire to handsel her new coach, and see her knights eastward castle, that the next morning will sweat with her busy setting forth, away will she and her mother, and while their preparation is making, ourselves with some two or three other friends will consummate the humble match, we have in gods name concluded.

lg.l: 'Tis to my wish; for I have often read,
Fit birth, fit age, keeps long a quiet bed.
'Tis to my wish; for tradesmen (Well 'tis known)
Get with more ease, than gentry keeps his own. Exit.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: My privy guest, lusty quicksilver, has drunk too deep of the bride-bowl, but with a little sleep he is much recovered; and I think is making himself ready, to be drunk in a gallanter likeness: my house is as 'twere the cave, where the young outlaw hoards the stolen vails of his occupation; and here when he will revel it in his prodigal similitude, he retires to his trunks, and (I may say softly) his punks: he dares trust me with the keeping of both: for I am security itself, my name is security, the famous usurer.

div.stage: Enter quicksilver in his prentices Cote and cap his gallant breeches and stockings, gartering himself. Security following.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Come old security, thou father of destruction: th'indented sheepskin is burned wherein I was wrapped, and I am now loose, to get more children of perdition into thy usurous bonds. Thou feedest my lechery, and I thy covetousness: thou art pandar to me for my wench, and I to thee for thy cozenages: K. me, K. thee, runs through court and country.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p:
Well said my subtle quicksilver, these ks open the
doors to all this world's felicity: the dullest forehead sees it. Let not mast. Courtier think he carries all the knavery on his shoulders: I have poor hob in the country, that has worn hobnails on's shoes, have as much villainy in's head, as he that wears gold buttons in's cap.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Why man, 'tis the London highway to thrist, if virtue be used; 'tis but as a scrap to the net of villainy. They that use it simply, thrive simply I warrant: weight and fashion makes goldsmith's cockolds.

div.stage: Enter sindefy, with Quicke-siluers doublet, cloak, rapier, and dagger.

sp.speaker: Synd.
sp.p: Here sir, put of the other half of your prenticeship.

sp.speaker: Quick.

lg.l: Well said sweet sin: bring forth my bravery.
Now let my trunks shoot forth their silks concealed,
I now am free; and now will justify
My trunks and punks: avant dull flatcap then,
Via, the curtain that shadowed Borgia;
There lie thou husk of my envassaled state.
I Sampson now, have burst the Philistins bands,
And in thy lap my lovely Dalida,
I'll lie and snore out my enfranchised state.
When Sampson was a tall young man
His power and strength increased then,
He should no more, nor cup, nor can,
But did them all despise.
Old Touchstone, now wright to thy friends,
For one to sell thy base gold ends
Quicksilver, now no more attends
Thee touchstone.

sp.p: But dad, hast thou seen my running gelding dressed today?

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: That I have frank, the ostler a'th cock, dressed him for a breakfast.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What did he eat him?

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p:
No, but he eat his breakfast for dressing him: and so dressed him for breakfast.
Quicksilver. O witty age, where age is young in wit,
And all youths words have grey beards full of it!

sp.speaker: Hyn.
sp.p: But alas Francke, how will all this be maintained now?

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.p: Why and I maintained my place. I'll to the court, another manner of place for maintenance I hope then the silly city. I heard my father say, I heard my mother sing an old song and a true: tou art a she fool, and knowest not what belongs to our male wisdom. I shall be a merchant forsooth: trust my estate in a wooden trough as he does? What are these ships, but tennis balls for the winds to play withal? Tossed from one wave to another; now underline; now over the house; sometimes brickwalled against a rock, so that the guts fly out again: sometimes struck under the wide Hazzard, and farewell mast. Marchant.

sp.speaker: Sindefy.
sp.p: Well Francke, well; the seas you say are uncertain: but he that sails in your court seas, shall find 'em ten times fuller of hazard; wherein to see what is to be seen, is torment more than a free spirit can endure; but when you come to suffer, how many injuries swallow you? What care and devotion must you use, to humour an imperious lord? proportion your looks to his looks? smiles to his smiles? fit your sails to the wind of his breath?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Tush he's no journeyman in his craft, that can not do that.

sp.speaker: Sindefy.
sp.p: But he's worse than a prentice that does it, not only humouring the lord, but every trencherbearer, every groom that by indulgence and intelligence crept into his favour, and by panarism into his chamber; he rules the roast: and when my honourable lord says it shall be thus, my worshipful rascal (The groom of his close stool) says it shall not be thus, claps the door after him, and who dares enter? A prentice, quoth you? 'tis but to learn to live, and does that disgrace a man? he that rises hardly, stands firmly: but he that rises with ease, alas, falls as easily.

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.p: A pox on you, who taught you this morality ?

sp.speaker: Security.
sp.p: 'Tis long of this witty age, master Francis. But indeed, mistress sindefy, all trades complain of inconvenience, and therefore 'tis best to have none. The merchant he complains, and says, traffic is subject to much uncertainty and loss: let 'em keep their goods on dry land with a vengeance, and not expose other men's substances to the mercy of the winds, under protection of a wooden wall (As master Francis says) and all for greedy desire, to enrich themselves with unconscionable gain, two for one, or so: where I, and such other honest men as live by lending money, are content with moderate profit; thirty, or forty i'th' hundred: so we may have it with quietness, and out of peril of wind and weather, rather than run those dangerous courses of trading, as they do.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I dad thou mayst well be called security, for thou takest the safest course.

sp.speaker: Security.
sp.p:
Faith the quieter, and the more contented; and, out of doubt, the more godly. For merchants in their courses are never pleased, but ever repining against heaven: one prays for a westerly wind to carry his ship forth; another for an easterly to bring his ship home; and at every shaking of a lease, he falls into an agony, to think what danger his ship is in on such a coast, and so forth. The farmer he is ever at odds with the weather, sometimes the clouds have been too barren; sometimes the heavens forget themselves, their harvests answer not their hopes; sometimes the season falls out too fruitful, corn will bear no price, and so forth. Th'artificer, he's all for a stirring world, if his trade be too full and fall short of his expectation, then falls he out of joint. Where we that trade nothing but money, are free from all this, we are pleased with all weathers: let it rain or hold up, be calm or windy, let the season be whatsoever, let trade go how it will, we take all in good part;
e'en what please the heavens to send us; so the sun stand not still; and the moon keep her usual returns; and make up days, months, and years.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And you have good security?

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: I marry Francke, that's the special point.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And yet forsooth we must have trades to live withal; for we cannot stand without legs, nor fly without wings; and a number of such scurvy phrases. No, I say still; he that has wit, let him live by his wit: he that has none, let him be a tradesman.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: Witty master Francis!

'Tis pity any trade should dull that quick brain of yours. Do but bring knight petronel into my parchment toils once, and you shall never need to toil in any trade, a my credit! You know his wife's land?

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.p: Even to a foot sir, I have been often there: a pretty fine seat, good land, all entire within itself.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: Well wooded?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Two hundered pounds worth of wood ready to fell. And a fine sweet house that stands just in the midst an't, like a prick in the midst of a circle; would I were your farmer, for a hundred pound a year.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: Excellent m. Francis; how I do long to do thee good: how I do hunger, and thirst to have the honour to enrich thee? Ay, even to die, that thou mightest inherit my living: even hunger and thirst, for a my religion, m. Francis. And so tell knight petrovell I do it to do him a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.p: Marry dad, his horses are now coming up, to bear down his lady, wilt thou lend him thy stable to set 'em in?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Faith m. Francis, I would be loath to lend my stable out of doors, in a greater matter I will pleasure him, but not in this.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
A pox of your hunger and thirst. Well dad, let him have money: all he could any way get, is bestowed on a ship, now bound for Virginia: the frame of which voyage is so closely conveyed, that his new lady nor any of her friends know it. Notwithstanding, as soon as his lady's hand is gotten to the
sale of her inheritance, and you have furnished him with money, he will instantly hoist sail, and away.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Now a frank gale of wind go with him, master Frank, we have too few such knight adventurers: who would not sell away competent certainties, to purchase (With any danger) excellent uncertainties? your true knight venturer ever does it. Let his wife seal today, he shall have his money today.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Tomorrow she shall, dad, before she goes into the country, to work her to which actio, with the more engines, I purpose presently to prefer my sweet sin here, to the place of her gentlewoman; whom you (For the more credit) shall present as your friend's daughter, a gentlewoman of the country, new come up with a will for a while to learn fashions forsooth, and be towards some lady; and she shall buzz pretty devises into her lady's ear; feeding her humours so serviceably (As the manner of such as she is you know.)

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: True good master Frances.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: That she shall keep her port open to any thing she commends to her.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: A'my religion, a most fashionable project; as good she spoil the lady, as the lady spoil her; for 'tis three to one of one side: sweet mistress sin, how are you bound to master Frances! I do not doubt to see you shortly wed one of the head men of our city.

sp.speaker: Sinne.
sp.p: But sweet Frank, when shall my father security present me?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: With all festination; I have broken the ice to it already; and will presently to the knight's house, whether, my good old dad, let me pray thee with all formality to man her.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Command me master Frances; I do hunger and thirst to do thee service. Come sweet mistress sin, take leave of my Winifrid, and we will instantly meet frank master Frances at your ladies.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Where is my cum there? Cum?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: I Winnie.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Wilt thou come in, sweet cum?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: I Wynney, presently. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: I Wynney, quod he? that's all he can do poor man; he may well cut off her name at Wynney. O 'tis an egregious Pandar! what will not an usurous knave be, so he may be rich? O 'tis a notable lews trump! I hope to live to see dogs meat made of the old usurer's flesh; dice of his bones; and indentures of his skin: and yet his skin is too thick to make parchment, 'twould make good boots for a Peter man to catch salmon in. Your only smooth skin to make fine vellum is your Puritans skin; they be the smoothest and slickest knaves in a country.

div.stage: Enter sir tetronell in boots with a riding wan.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: I'll out of this wicked town as fast as my horse can trot: here's now no good action for a man to spend his time in. Taverns grow dead; ordinaries are blown up; plays are at a stand; houses of hospitality at a fall; not a feather waving, nor a spur gingling anywhere : I'll away instantly.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Y'ad best take some crowns in your purse knight, or else your eastward castle will smoke but miserably.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: O Francke! my castle? Alas all the castles I have, are built with air, thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: I know it knight, and therefore wonder whether your lady is going.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Faith to seek her fortune I think. I said I had a castle and land eastward, and eastward she will without contradiction; her coach, and the coach of the sun must meet full butt: and the sun being out shined with her Ladyship's glory, she fears he goes westward to hang himself.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: And I fear, when her enchanted castle becomes invisible, her ladyship will return and follow his example.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: O that she would have the grace, for I shall never be able to pacific her, when she sees herself deceived so.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p:
As easily as can be. Tell her she mistook your directions, and that shortly, yourself will down with her to approve it; and then, cloth but her croupper in a new
gown, and you may drive her any way you list: for these women sir, are like Essex calves, you must wriggle 'em on by the tail still, or they will never drive orderly.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: But alas sweet Francke, thou knowest my hability will not furnish her blood with those costly humours.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Cast that cost on me sir, I have spoken to my old pander security, for money or commodity; and commodity (If you will) I know he will procure you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Commodity! Alas what commodity?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why sir? what say you to figs, and raisins?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: A plague of figs and raisins, and all such frail commodities, we shall make nothing of 'em.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Why then sir, what say you to forty pound in roasted beef?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Out upon't, I have less stomach to that, then to the figs and raisins: I'll out of town, though I sojourn with a friend of mine, for stay here I must not; my creditors have laid to arrest me, and I have no friend under heaven but my sword to bail me.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: God's me knight, put 'em in sufficient sureties, rather than let your sword bail you; let 'em take their choice, either the King's bench, or the fleet, or which of the two counters they like best, for by the lord I like none of 'em.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Well Frank there is no jesting with my earnest necessity; thou knowest if I make not present money to further my voyage begun all's lost, and all I have laid out about it.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why then sir in earnest, if you can get your wise lady to set her hand to the sale of her inheritance, the blood hound security will smell out ready money for you instantly.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: There spoke an angel. To bring her to which conformity, I must feign myself extremely amorous; and alleging urgent excuses for my stay, behind, part with her as passionately, as she would from her foisting hound.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
You have the sow by the right ear sir: I warrant there was never child longed more to ride a cock horse, or wear his new coat, than she longs to ride in her new coach:
she would long for every thing when she was a maid; and now she will run mad for 'em: I say my life she will have every year four children; and what charge and change of humour you must endure while she is with child; and how she will tie you to your tackling till she be with child, a dog would not endure: nay, there is no turnspit dog bound to his wheel more seruily, than you shall be to her wheel; for as that dog can never climb the top of his wheel, but when the top comes under him: so shall you never climb the top of her contentment, but when she is under you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: 'Slight how thou terrifiest me?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Nay hark you sir; what nurses, what midwives, what fools, what physicians, what cunning women must be sought for (Fearing sometimes she is bewitched, some times in a consumption) to tell her tales, to talk bawdy to her, to make her laugh, to give her glisters, to let her blood under the tongue, and betwixt the toes; how she will revile and kiss you; spit in your face, and lick it off again; how she will vaunt you are her creature; she made you of nothing; how she could have had thousand mark jointures; she could have been made a lady by a Scotch knight; and never ha' married him: she could have had poynados in her bed every morning; how she set you up, and how she will pull you down: you'll never be able to stand of your legs to endure it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Out of my fortune, what a death is my life bound face to face too? The best is, a large time-fitted conscience is bound to nothing: marriage is but a form in the school of policy, to which scholars sit fastened only with painted chains, old securities young wife is never the further of with me.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Thereby lies a tale sir. The old usurer will be here instantly, with my punk Sindefy, whom you know your lady has promised me to entertain for her gentlewoman: and he (With a purpose to feed on you) invites you most solemnly by me to supper.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: It falls out excellently fitly: I see desire of gain makes jealousy venturous:Enter Gyrt:
See Francke here comes my lady; lord how she views thee, she knows thee not I think in this bravery.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: How now? who be you I pray?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: One master Frances quicksilver, an't please your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: God's my dignity! as I am a lady, if he did not make me blush so that mine eyes stood awater, would I were unmarried again:Enter security and Sindefy.
Where's my woman I pray?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: See madam, she now comes to attend you.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: God save my honourable knight, and his worshipful lady.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: You're very welcome! you must not put on your hat yet.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: No madam; till I know your ladyships further pleasure, I will not presume.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: And is this a gentleman's daughter new come out of the country?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: She is madam; and one that her father hath a special care to bestow in some honourable lady's service, to put her out of her honest humours forsooth, for she had a great desire to be a nun, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: A nun? what nun? A nun substantive? or a nun adjective?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: A nun substantive madam I hope, if a nun be a noun. But I mean, lady, a vowed maid of that order.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: I'll teach her to be a maid of the order I warrant you: and can you do any work belongs to a lady's chamber?

sp.speaker: Synde.
sp.p: What I cannot do, madam, I would be glad to learn.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Well said, hold up then; hold up your head I say, come hither a little.

sp.speaker: Synd.
sp.p: I thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: And hark you; good man, you may put on your hat now, I do not look on you: I must have you of my faction now; not of my knights, maid.

sp.speaker: Synd.
sp.p: No forsooth madam of yours.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p:
And draw all my servants in my bow, and keep my counsel, and tell me tales, and put me riddles and read on a book sometimes when I am busy, and laugh at country gentlewomen, and command any thing in the house for my retainers, and care not what you spend, for it is all mine; and in
any case, be still a maid whatsoever you do, or whatsoever any man can do unto you.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: I warrant your ladyship for that.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Very well, you shall ride in my coach with me into the country tomorrow morning; come knight, pray thee let's make a short supper, and to bed presently.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Nay good madam, this night I have a short supper at home, waits on his worship's acceptation.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: By my faith but he shall not go sir; I shall swoon and he sup from me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Pray thee forbear; shall he lose his provision?

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: I by lady sir, rather than I lose my longing; come in I say: as I am a lady you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: I told him what a burr he had gotten.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: If you will not sup from your knight madam, let me entreat your ladyship to sup at my house with him.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: No by my faith sir, than we cannot be a-bed soon enough, after supper.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What a medicine is this? well master security, you are new married as well as I; I hope you are bound as well: we must honour our young wives you know.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: In policy dad, till tomorrow she has sealed.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: I hope in the morning yet your knighthood will breakfast with me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: As early as you will sir.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Thank your good worship; I do hunger and thirst to do you good sir.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Come sweet knight come, I do hunger and thirst to be a-bed with thee. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus tertii. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Petronell, quicksilver, security, bramble, and Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p:
Thanks for our feastlike breakfast good master security, I am sorry, (By reason of my instant haste to so long a voyage as Virginia,) I am without means, by any kind
amends to show how affectionately I take your kindness, and to confirm by some worthy ceremony a perpetual league of friendship betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Excellent knight; let this be a token betwixt us of inviolable friendship: I am new married to this fair gentlewoman you know; and (By my hope to make her fruitful though I be something in years) I vow faithfully unto you, to make you godfather (Though in your absence) to the first child I am blessed withal; and henceforth call me gossip I beseech you, if you please to accept it.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: In the highest degree of gratitude, my most worthy gossip; for confirmation of which friendly title, let me entreat my fair gossip your wife here, to accept this diamond, and keep it as my gift to her first child, wheresoever my fortune in event of my voyage shall bestow me.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: How now my coy wedlock! make you strange of so noble a favour? take it I charge you, with all affection, and (By way of taking your leave) present boldly your lips to our honourable gossip.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: How venturous he is to him, and how jealous to others!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Long may this kind touch of our lips print in our hearts all the forms of affection. And now my good gossip, if the writings be ready to which my wife should seal, let them be brought this morning, before she takes coach into the country, and my kindness shall work her to dispatch it.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: The writings are ready sir. My learned counsel here, master Bramble, the lawyer hath perused them; and within this hour, I will bring the scrivener with them to your worshipful lady.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Good master Bramble, I will here take my leave of you then; God send you fortunate pleas sir, and contentious clients.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: And you foreright winds sir, and a fortunate voyage. Exit. Enter a messenger.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Sir petronel, here are three or four gentlemen desire to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: They are your followers in this voyage knight, captain seagull and his associates, I met them this morning, and told them you would be here.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Let them enter I pray you, I know they long to be gone, for their stay is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: God save my honourable colonel.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Welcome good captain seagull, and worthy gentlemen, if you will meet my friend Francke here, and me, at the blue anchor tavern by Billingsgate this evening, we will there drink to our happy voyage, be merry, and take boat to our ship with all expedition.

sp.speaker: Spoil.
sp.p: Defer it no longer I beseech you sir, but as your voyage is hitherto carried closely, and in another knight's name, so for your own safety and ours, let it be continued, our meeting and speedy purpose of departing known to as few as is possible, lest your ship and goods be attached.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well advised captain our colonel shall have money this morning to dispatch all our departures, bring those gentlemen at night to the place appointed, and with our skins full of vintage, we'll take occasion by the vantage, and away.

sp.speaker: Spoil.
sp.p: We will not fail but be there sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Good morrow good captain, and my worthy associates. Health and all sovereignty to my beautiful gossip, for you sir, we shall see you presently with the writings.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: With writings and crowns to my honourable gossip: I do hunger and thirst to do you good sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus tertii. Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter a coachman in haste in's frock feeding.

sp.speaker: Coachman
sp.p: Here's a stir when citizens ride out of town indeed, as if all the house were a fire; slight they will not give a man leave, to eat's breakfast afore he rises.

div.stage: Enter Hamlet a footman in haste.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What coachman? my lady's coach for shame; her ladyship's ready to come down;

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.p: Sfoot Hamlet; are you mad? whether run you now you should brush up my old mistress?

sp.speaker: Synd.
sp.p: What potkin? you must put off your tankard, and put on your blue coat and wait upon mistress Toochstone into the country. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.p: I will forsooth presently. Exit.

div.stage: Enter mistress fond, and mistress gazer.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: Come sweet mistress gazer, let's watch here, and see my lady flash take coach.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: A my word here's a most fine place to stand in, did you see the new ship launched last day mistress fond.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: O God, and we citizens should lose such a sight?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: I warrant, here will be double as many people to see her take coach, as there were to see it take water.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: O she's married to a most fine castle 'Ith' country they say?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: But there are no giants in the castle, are there?

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: O no, they say her knight killed 'em all and therefore he was knighted.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Would to God her ladyship would come away.

div.stage: Enter gyr. mistress touch. Synd. Ham. Por.

sp.speaker: Fond.
sp.p: She comes, she comes, she comes.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.p: Fond. Pray heaven bless your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Thank you good people; my coach for the love of heaven, my coach? in good truth I shall swoon else.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Coach? coach my lady's coach. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: As I am a lady, I think I am with child already, I long for a coach so; may one be with child afore they are married mother?

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: I by'r lady madam, a little thing does that; I have seen a little prick no bigger than a pin's head, swell bigger and bigger, till it has come to an ancome; and e'en so 'tis in these cases.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Your coach is coming, madam.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
Mistress Touch.
sp.p: But must this young man, an't please you madam, run by your coach all the way a foot?

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: I by my faith I warrant him, he gives no other milk, as I have another servant does.

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: Alas! 'tis e'en pity methinks ; for god's sake madam buy him but a hobby horse, let the poor youth have something betwixt his legs to ease 'em; alas! we must do as we would be done too;

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Go too, hold your peace dame, you talk like an old fool I tell you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Wilt thou be gone, sweet honey suckle, before I can go with thee?

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: I pray thee sweet knight let me; I do so long to dress up thy castle afore thou comest: but I mar'le how my modest sister occupies herself this morning, that she can not wait on me to my coach, as well as her mother!

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Marry madam, she's married by this time to prentice Goulding; your father, and some one more, stole to church with 'em, in all the haste, that the cold meat lest at your wedding, might serve to furnish their nuptial table.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: There's no base fellow, my father, now: but he's e'en fit to father such a daughter: he must call me daughter no more now; but madam; and please you madam: and please your worship madam, indeed; out upon him, marry his daughter to a base prentice?

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: What should one do? is there no law for one that marries a woman's daughter against her will? how shall we punish him madam.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: As I am a lady an't would snow, we'd so pebble 'em with snow balls as they come from church; but sirrah, frank quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I madam.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: Dost remember since thou and I clapped what-do-you-call-its' in the garret?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I know not what you mean madam.

sp.speaker: Gyr.

lg.l: His head as white as milk,
All flaxen was his hair:
But now he is dead,
And laid in his bed,
And never will come again.

sp.p: God be at your labour.

div.stage: Enter touch. Gould. Mild. with rosemary.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Was there ever such a lady?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: See madam, the bride and bridegroom:

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: God's my precious! God give you joy mistress what lack you. Now out upon thee baggage: my sister married in a taffeta hat? Marry hang you; westward with a wanion te'yee, nay I have done we ye minion then i'faith, never look to have my countenance any more: nor any thing I can do for thee. Thou ride in my coach? or come down to my castle? fie upon thee: I charge thee in my ladyship's name, call me sister no more.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: An't please your worship, this is not your sister: this is my daughter, and she call me father, and so does not your ladyship an't please your worship madam.

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: No nor she must not call thee father by heraldry, because thou mak'st thy prentice thy son as well as she; ah thou misproud prentice, dar'st thou presume to marry a lady's sister?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: It pleased my master forsooth to embolden me with his favour: and though I confess myself far unworthy so worthy a wife (Being in part, her servant, as I am your prentice) yet (Since I may say it without boasting) I am born a gentleman, and by the trade I have learned of my master (Which I trust taints not my blood) able with mine own industry and portion to maintain your daughter, my hope is, heaven will so bless our humble beginning, that in the end I shall be no disgrace to the grace with which my master hath bound me his double prentice.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Master me no more son if thou think'st me worthy to be thy father.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Sun? Now good lord how he shines and you mark him! he's a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I indeed madam, a gentleman born.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Never stand a'your gentry m. Bridegroom: if your legs be no better than your arms, you'll be able to stand upon neither shortly.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: An't please your good worship sir, there are two sorts of gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Bold to put off my hat to your worship.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay pray forbear sir, and then forth with your two sorts of gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: If your worship will have it so? I say there are two sorts of gentlemen. There is a gentleman artificial, and a gentleman natural; now, though your worship be a gentleman natural: work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well said old Touchstone, I am proud to hear thee enter a set speech i'faith, forth I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, your worship's a gentleman, I do not know? if you be one of my acquaintance you're very much disguised sir.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Go too old quipper: forth with thy speech I say.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What sir, my speeches were ever in vain to your gracious worship: and therefore till I speak to you gallantry in deed, I will save my breath for my broth anon. Come my poor son and daughter; let us hide ourselves in our poor humility and live safe: ambition consumes itself, with the very show. Work upon that now.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Let him go, let him go for god's sake: let him make his prentice, his son for God's sake: give away his daughter for God's sake: and when they come a-begging to us for God's sake, let's laugh at their good husbandry for God's sake. Farewell sweet knight, pray thee make haste after.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What shall I say? I would not have thee go,

sp.speaker: Quick.

lg.l: Now, oh now, I must depart;
Parting though it absence move,
This ditty knight, do I see in thy looks in capital letters.
What a grief 'tis to depart, and leave the slower that has my heart?
My sweet lady, and alack for we, why should we part so?

sp.p: Tell truth knight, and shame all dissembling lovers; does not your pain lie on that side?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: If it do, canst thou tell me how I may cure it?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Excellent easily; divide yourself in two halves, just by the girdlestead; send one half with your lady, and keep the tother yourself: or else do as all true lovers do, part with your heart and leave your body behind: I have seen't done a hundred times: 'tis as easy a matter for a lover to part without a heart from his sweet heart, and he never the worse: as for a mouse to get from a trap and leave her tail behind him. See here comes the writings.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: Good morrow to my worshipful lady. I present your ladyship with this writing; to which if you please to set your hand, with your knights, a velvet gown shall attend your journey a'my credit.

sp.speaker: Gir.
sp.p: What writing is it knight?

sp.speaker: Petrenell.
sp.p: The sale (Sweet heart) of the poor tenement I told thee off, only to make a little money to send thee down furniture for my castle, to which my hand shall lead thee.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Very well: now give me your pen I pray.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: It goes down without chewing i'faith.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p: Your worships deliver this as your deed?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: So now knight farewell till I see thee.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: All farewell to my sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Mistress Touch.
sp.p: Good-bye, son knight.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Farewell my good mother.

sp.speaker: Gyr.
sp.p: Farewell Francke, I would fain take thee down if I could.

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.p: I thank your good ladyship; farewell mistress Sindefy. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O tedious voyage, where of there is no end! What will they think of me?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Think what they list; they longed for a vagary into the country, and now they are fitted: so a woman marry to ride in a coach, she cares not if she ride to her ruin; 'tis the great end of many of their marriages: this is not first time a
lady has rid a false journey in her coach I hope.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis no matter, I care little what they think; he that ways men's thoughts, has his hands full of nothing: a man in the course of this world should be like a surgeon's instrument, work in the wounds of others, and feel nothing himself. The sharper, and subtler, the better.

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.p: As it falls out now knight, you shall not need to devise excuses, or endure her out cries, when she returns; we shall now be gone before, where they can not reach us.

sp.speaker: Petronel.
sp.p: Well my kind compeer, you have now th'assurance we both can make you; let me now entreat you, the money we agreed on may be brought to the blue anchor, near to Billingsgate, by six o'clock : where I and my chief friends, bound for this voyage, will with feasts attend you.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: The money my most honourable compeer, shall without fail observe your appointed hour.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Thanks my dear gossip. I must now impart
To your approved love, a loving secret:
As one on whom my life doth more rely
In friendly trust, than any man alive.
Nor shall you be the chosen secretary
Of my affections, for affection only;
For I protest, (If God bless my return,)
To make you partner, in my actions gain
As deeply, as if you had ventured with me
Half my expenses. Know then, honest gossip,
I have enjoyed with such divine contentment,
A gentle woman's bed, whom you well know,
That I shall ne'er enjoy this tedious voyage,
Nor live the lest part of the time it asketh,
Without her presence; so I thirst and hunger
To taste the dear feast of her company.
And if the hunger and the thirst you vow
(As my sworn gossip) to my wished good
Be (As I know it is) unfeigned and firm,
Do me an easy favour in your power.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.l: Be sure brave gossip, all that I can do
to my best nerve, is wholly at your service:
Who is the woman (First) that is your friend?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The woman is your learned counsels wife,
The lawyer master Bramble: whom would you,
Bring out this even, in honest neighbourhood
To take his leave with you, of me your gossip.
Ay, in the mean time, will send this my friend
Home to his house, to bring his wife disguised
Before his face, into our company:
For love hath made her look for such a wile,
To free her from his tyrannous jealousy.
And I would take this course before another:
In stealing her away to make us sport,
And gull his circumspection the more grossly.
And I am sure that no man like yourself,
Hath credit with him to entice his jealousy,
To so long stay abroad, as may give time
To her enlargement, in such safe disguise.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.l: A pretty, pithy, and most pleasant project!
Who would not strain a point of neighbourhood,
For such a point, device? that as the ship
Of famous Draco, went about the world,
Will wind about the lawyer, compassing,
The world himself, he hath it in his arms:
And that's enough, for him, without his wife.
A lawyer is ambitious, and his head,
Can not be praised, nor raised too high,
With any fork, of highest knavery.
I'll go fetch her straight. Exit security.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: So, so, now Frank go thou home to his house,
Stead of his lawyers, and bring his wife hither:
Who just like to the lawyer's wife, is prisoned,
With his stern usurous jealousy; which could never
Be over reacht-thus, but with overreaching. Enter security.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.l: And m. Francis, watch you th'instant time
To enter with his exit: 'twill be rare,
Two fine horned beasts a camel and a lawyer!

sp.speaker: Quicksilver.
sp.l: How the old villain joys in villainy?
And hark you gossip, when you have her here,
Have your boat ready, ship her to your ship
With utmost haste, lest master Bramble stay you,
To o'er reach that head that outreacheth all heads?
'Tis a trick rampant; 'tis a very Quiblyn;
I hope this harvest, to pitch cart with lawyers;
Their heads will be so forked; this sly touch
Will get apes to invent a number such. Exit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Was ever rascal, honeyed so with poison?
He that delights in slavish avarice.
Is apt to joy in every sort of vice.
Well, I'll go fetch his wife, whilst he the lawyers.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: But stay Frank, let's think how we may disguise her upon this sudden.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: God's me there's the mischief; but hark you, here's an excellent device; fore God a rare one: I will carry her a sailor's gown and cap and cover her; and a player's beard;

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And what upon her head?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I tell you a sailor's cap: slight God forgive me, what kind of figent memory have you?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay then, what kind of figent wit hast thou?
A sailor's cap? how shall she put it off
When thou presentest her to our company?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Tush man, for that, make her a saucy sailor.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Tush tush 'tis no fit sauce for such sweet mutton; I know not what t'advise.

div.stage: Enter secur ▪ with his wife's gown.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Knight, knight a rare device.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: 'Sounds yet again.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: What stratagem have you now?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: The best that ever. You talked of disguising?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I may gossip that's our present care.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.l: Cast care a way then, here's the best device
For plain security (For I am no better)
I think that ever lived: here's my wife's gown
Which you may put upon the lawyer's wife,
And which I brought you sir for two great reasons;
One is, that master Bramble may take hold
Of some suspicion that it is my wife,
and gird me so perhaps with his law wit,
The other (Which is policy indeed)
Is, that my wife may now be tied at home,
Having no more but her old gown abroad,
And not show me a quirk, while I firk others.
Is not this rare?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: The best that ever she's.

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Am I not born to furnish gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O my dear gossip!

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Well hold master Francis, watch when the lawyer's out, and put it in; and now — I will go fetch him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: O my dad! he goes as 'twere the devil to fetch the lawyer; and devil shall he be if horns will make him.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why how now gossip, why stay you there musing?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: A toy, a toy runs in my head i'faith.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A pox of that head, is there more toys yet?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What is it pray thee gossip?

sp.speaker: Secur.
sp.p: Why sir? what if you should slip away now with my wife's best gown. I having no security for it?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: For that I hope dad you will take our words.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.l: I by th'mass your word that's a proper staff
For wise security to lean upon;
But 'tis no matter, once I'll trust my name,
On your cracked credits, let it take no shame,
Fetch the wench Frank. Exit.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.l: I'll wait upon you sir.
And fetch you over, you were ne'er so fetched:
Go, to the tavern knight, your followers
Dare not be drunk I think, before their captain. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Would I might lead them to no hotter service,
Till our Virginian gold were in our pursesExit.

div.stage: Enter Seagull Spendall and Scapthrift in the tavern with a drawer.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: Come drawer, pierce your neatest hogsheads, and let's have cheer, not fit for your Billingsgate tavern; but for our Virginian colonel; he will be here instantly.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: You shall have all things fit sir; please you have any more wine.

sp.speaker: Spend,
sp.p: More wine slave? whether we drink it or no, spill it, and draw more.

sp.speaker: Scap.
sp.p: Fill all the pots in your house with all sorts of liquour, and let 'em wait on us here like soldiers in their pewter, coats; and though we do not employ them now, yet we will maintain 'em, till we do.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Said like an honourable captain; you shall have all you can command sir. Exit drawer.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Come boys, Virginia longs till we share the rest of her maidenhead,

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why is she inhabited already with any English?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: A whole country of English is there man, bred of those that were left there in 79. They have married with the Indians, and make 'em bring forth as beautiful faces as any we have in England: and therefore the Indians are so in love with 'em, that all the treasure they have, they lay at their feet.

sp.speaker: Scap.
sp.p: But is there such treasure there captain, as I have heard?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: I tell thee, gold is more plentiful there then copper is with us: and for as much red copper as I can bring, I'll have thrice the weight in gold. Why man all their dripping pans and their chamber pots are pure gold; and all the chains, with which they chain up their streets, are massy gold; all the prisoners they take, are fettered in gold: and for rubies and diamonds, they go forth on holidays and gather 'em by the seashore, to hang on their children's coats, and stick in their caps, as commonly as our children wear saffron guilt brooches, and groats with holes in 'em.

sp.speaker: Scap.
sp.p: And is it a pleasant country withal?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p:
As ever the sun shined on: temperate and full of all sorts of excellent viands; wild boar is as common there, as our tamest bacon is here: venison, as mutton. And than you shall live freely there, without sergeants, or courtiers, or lawyers, or intelligencers. Then for your means to advancement, there, it is simple, and not preposterously
mixed: you may be an alderman there, and never be scavenger; you may be any other officer, and never be a slave. You may come to preferment enough, and never be a

sp.speaker: Pandar.
sp.p: To riches, and fortune enough and have never the more villainy, nor the less wit. Besides, there, we shall have no more law than conscience, and not too much of either; serve God enough, eat and drink enough, and enough is as good as a feast.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God's me! and how far is it thither?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Some six weeks sail, no more, with any indifferent good wind: and if I get to any part of the coast of Africa, I'll sail thither with any wind. Or when I come to cape Finister, there's a foreright wind continual wastes us till we come at Virginia. See, our colonel's come.

div.stage: Enter sir Petronell with his followers.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Well met good captain seagull, and my noble gentlemen! Now the sweet hour of our freedom is at hand.
Come drawer. Fill us some carouses; and prepare us for the mirth, that will be occasioned presently: here will be a pretty wench gentlemen, that will bear us company all our voyage.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Whatsoever she be; here's to her health noble colonel, both with cap and knee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Thanks kind captain seagull. She's one I love dear; and must not be known till we be free from all that know us: and so gentlemen, here's to her health.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Let it come worthy colonel, we do hunger and thirst for it,

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Afore heaven, you have hit the phrase of one that her presence will touch, from the foot to the forehead, if ye knew it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why then we will join his forehead, with her health, sir: and captain Scapethrift, here's to 'em both,

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: See, see, master Bramble; fore heaven their voyage cannot but prosper, they are o'their knees for success to it.

sp.speaker: Bram.
sp.p: And they pray to God Bacchus.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: God save my brave colonel with all his tall captains and corporals; see sir, my worshipful learned counsel, m. Bramble, is come to take his leave of you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Worshipful m. Bramble, how far do you draw us into the sweet briar of your kindness? come captain seagull, another health to this rare bramble, that hath never a prick about him.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: I pledge his most smooth disposition sir: come master security, bend your supporters, and pledge this notorious health here.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: Bend you yours likewise, m. Bramble, for it is you shall pledge me.

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: Not so, m. security, he must not pledge his own health.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: No master captain? Enter quicksilver with Winny disguised.
Why then here's one is fitly come to do him that honour.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Here's the gentlewoman your cousin sir, whom with much entreaty I have brought to take her leave of you in a tavern; ashamed whereof, you must pardon her if she put not off her mask.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Pardon me sweet cousin, my kind desire to see you before I went, made me so importunate to entreat your presence here.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: How now m. Frances? have you honoured this presence with a fair gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Pray sir, take you no notice of her, for she will not be known to you.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: But my learned counsel, m. Bramble here, I hope may know her.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No more than you sir, at this time, his learning must pardon her.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p:
Well, God pardon her for my part, and I do I'll be
sworn; and so master Francis, here's to all that are going eastward tonight , towards cuckold's haven; and so to the health of master Bramble.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I pledge it sir, hath it gone round, captains?

sp.speaker: Sea.
sp.p: It has sweet Frank, and the round closes with thee.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Well sir, here's to all eastward and towards cuckolds, and so to famous cuckold's haven so fatally remembered. Surgit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay pray thee coz weep not; gossip security?

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: I my brave gossip.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A word I beseech you sir; our friend, mistress Bramble here, is so dissolved in tears, that she drowns the whole mirth of our meeting: sweet gossip, take her aside and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Secu.
sp.p: Pity of all true love, mistress Bramble, what weep you to enjoy your love? what's the cause lady? is't because your husband is so near, and your heart earns, to have a little abused him?
